text: IPv4 addresses were deployed in 1981 and have 4.3 billion possible addresses. Example: 40.112.72.205

IPv6 addresses were deployed in 1998 and have 340 undecillion possible addresses. Example: 2001:4998:0024:120d:0000:0000:0001:0001 or 2001:4998:24:120d::1:1. Note: IPv6 addresses are so long, there are rules for shortening them! The two IPv6 addresses above are actually the same address, the bottom address just had any leading zeros removed.
Maxmind.com - Maxmind provides free information about IP addresses, including the ISP and city-level geolocation accuracy. The premium data includes user type (cellular, residential, business, etc.).
IPQualityScore.com - IPQS provides 5,000 free lookups a month as well as information on ISP, city-level accuracy, proxy/VPN/Tor status, etc.
IKnowWhatYouDownload.com - I KNOW allows you to see any peer-to-peer (P2P) file sharing activity from an IP address.
Shodan.io - Shodan is a technology-focused search engine that allows you to see what services are running on a system and other detailed information.

Search.Censys.io - Censys is a technology-focused search engine that allows you to see what services are running on a system and other detailed information on known vulnerabilities and SSL certificates.

Greynoise.io - GreyNoise catalogs traffic flowing across the internet, allowing you to determine if activity from an IP address is targeted towards a specific group or indiscriminately scanning the internet.
AbuseIPDB.com - AbuseIPDB is a central repository for reporting IP addresses that have been associated with malicious online activity.
Internal IP Addresses - These internal IP addresses are usually of little interest to OSINT investigators: 10.X.X.X, 172.16.X.X-172.31.X.X, 192.168.X.X-192.168.X.X, 127.0.0.1 (localhost)
Google Search Operator: "[term]" - Function: Search exact phrase in quotes - Example: "HGTV Shows"
Google Search Operator: [term] OR [term] - Function: Search for either term - Example: tv OR streaming
Google Search Operator: [term] AROUND(n) [term] - Function: Search for a term within n words of another term - Example: stream AROUND(5) "HGTV Shows"
Google Search Operator: @[term] - Function: Search social media for a handle - Example: @hgtv

metadata.title: Google Search Operator - Social Media Handle

text: Google Search Operator: -[term] - Function: Exclude a term - Example: "fixer upper" "stream" -HGTV
Google Search Operator: filetype:[type] - Function: Only show results with a certain file type, such as xlsx or pdf - Example: site:hgtv.com filetype:pdf
Google Search Operator: ([operations]) - Function: Group operations together to control how a complex search executes - Example: site:gov wifi (password OR key)
Google Search Operator: site: - Function: Limit results to a specific site or class of site - Example: site:gov or site:example.com
Google Search Operator: intitle:[term] - Function: Search for one term in the title of a page - Example: intitle:hgtv | site:hgtv.com
Google Search Operator: allintitle:[term] - Function: Search for all of the terms that follow the : in the title of the HTML page - Example: allintitle:bbc news | site:bbc.com
Google Search Operator: inurl:[term] - Function: Find sites with one term in URL - Example: inurl:magnolia | site:magnolia.com
Google Search Operator: allinurl:[term] - Function: Find sites with multiple terms in URL - Example: inurl:magnolia table site:magnolia.com
Google Search Operator: intext:[term] - Function: Search for occurrences of a term in website text - Example: intext:waco | site:magnolia.com
Google Search Operator: allintext:[term] - Function: Search for occurrences of multiple terms in website text - Example: allintext:silo shops site:magnolia.com
Google Search Operator: link:[url] - Function: Find pages that link to a page, but doesn't seem to work consistently - Example: link:www.magnolia.com site:www.magnolia.com
Google Search Operator: before:[Date] after:[Date] - Function: Find results before or after a specific date or year, or in between a specific date range - Example: before:2020 after:2015-7
Google Search Operator: [n]..[n] - Function: Put .. between two numbers to search a range (not super accurate) - Example: nikon $300..$500
Shodan Search Syntax: city:"[city name]" - Searches for devices in a specific city
Shodan Search Syntax: country:"[country code]" - Searches for devices in a specific country
Shodan Search Syntax: hostname:"[hostname]" - Searches for devices with a specific hostname
Shodan Search Syntax: net:"[IP range]" - Searches for devices within a specific IP range
Shodan Search Syntax: os:"[operating system]" - Searches for devices with a specific operating system
Shodan Search Syntax: port:"[port number]" - Searches for devices with a specific port
Shodan Search Syntax: org:"[organization name]" - Searches for devices associated with a specific organization
Shodan Search Syntax: isp:"[internet service provider]" - Searches for devices using a specific internet service provider
Shodan Search Syntax: product:"[product name]" - Searches for devices that are using a specific software or hardware product
Shodan Search Syntax: version:"[version number]" - Searches for devices running a specific version of software or firmware
Shodan Search Syntax: has_screenshot:"true" - Searches for devices with available screenshots
Shodan Search Syntax: ssl.cert.subject.cn:"[common name]" - Searches for SSL certificates with a specific common name
Shodan Search Syntax: http.title:"[title text]" - Searches for web pages with a specific title
Shodan Search Syntax: http.html:"[html content]" - Searches for web pages containing specific HTML content
Shodan Search Syntax: before:"[date]" | after:"[date]" - Searches for devices that were online before or after a specific date
Shodan Search Syntax: webcam - Searches for internet-connected webcams
Example Shodan Search: "default password" - Searches for devices using default passwords
Example Shodan Search: "MongoDB Server Information" port:27017 -authentication - Finds exposed MongoDB databases
Example Shodan Search: "in-tank inventory" port:10001 - Finds gas station pump controllers
Censys Host Search Syntax: Single IP (supports IPv4 and IPv6) - 8.8.8.8
Censys Host Search Syntax: Subnet by CIDR - ip: "8.0.0.0/8"
Censys Host Search Syntax: Subnet by IP range - ip: [1.12.0.0 to 1.15.255.255]
Censys Host Search Syntax: By TLD - dns.names: "*.su"
Censys Host Search Syntax: Autonomous System Number (ASN) - autonomous_system.asn:6167
Censys Host Search Syntax: Single port - services.port:80
Censys Host Search Syntax: Any of these ports - services.port:{22,80,443}
Censys Host Search Syntax: Service - services.service_name:SSH
Censys Host Search Syntax: Labels - labels: c2. Other label options include: ics, login-page and open-dir
Censys Certificate Search Syntax: Self-signed certificates for a domain - (cellebrite.com) and labels='self-signed'
Censys Certificate Search Syntax: Certificates issued by a specific organization - parsed.issuer.organization='Internet Widgits Pty Ltd'
Example Censys Search: Roombas - services.tls.certificates.leaf_data.issuer.common_name: "Roomba CA"
Example Censys Search: Brute Ratel servers - services.http.response.body_hash="sha1:1a279f5df4103743b823ec2a6a08436fdf63fe30"
Example Censys Search: ICS Protocols - services.service_name: {BACNET, CODESYS, EIP, FINS, FOX, IEC60870_5_104, S7, MODBUS}
Useful Google Alerts - Example Alerts for Force Protection/Situational Awareness: (hancock) AND (john OR sally OR kevin) AND ("123 main st" OR 530-555-1212 OR 520-555-1212)
Useful Google Alerts - Example Alerts for Force Protection/Situational Awareness: (email@test.org) AND ("123 main st" OR 530-555-1212 OR 520-555-1212)
Useful Google Alerts - Example Alerts for Brand/Reputation Monitoring: ("Globex Industries") AND ("scandal" OR "fraud" OR "hate" OR "terrible" OR "scam")
Useful Google Alerts - Example Alerts for Brand/Reputation Monitoring: ("Wonka Industries") AND ("food safety violation" OR "product contamination" OR "factory shutdown")
Useful Google Alerts - Example Alerts for Brand/Reputation Monitoring: ("Pied Piper") AND ("patent infringement" OR "intellectual property theft" OR "copyright violation")
Useful Google Alerts - Example Alerts for Cybersecurity Awareness: ("Acme Corporation" OR acmecorp.com) AND ("vulnerability" OR "exploit" OR "zero-day")
Useful Google Alerts - Example Alerts for Cybersecurity Awareness: ("industry sector") AND ("cyber attack" OR "data breach" OR "security incident")
Useful Google Alerts - Example Alerts for Cybersecurity Awareness: ("supply chain" OR "third-party vendor") AND ("cyber risk" OR "data breach" OR "security vulnerability")
Useful OSINT API: Grayhatwarfare.com - Grayhat Warfare monitors for exposed data in cloud buckets.
Useful OSINT API: PeopleDataLabs.com - People Data Labs allows you to search by email address, phone number, name, etc., and retrieve records.
Useful OSINT API: IPQualityScore.com - IPQS allows 5,000 lookups a month for IP addresses, email addresses, etc.
Useful OSINT API: Shodan.io - Shodan searches for devices connected to the internet, including servers, webcams, and IoT devices.

AI Resources for OSINT: ChatGPT - ChatGPT is a large language model (LLM) useful for helping with writing Python code, analyzing code, writing reports, generating biographical information for sock puppet accounts, and more.
AI Resources for OSINT: Claude AI - Claude AI is a LLM similar to ChatGPT but with an emphasis on writing quality content.

AI Resources for OSINT: Whisper - Whisper is a transcription engine which generates text output from audio/video files. It automatically detects what language is being used in the video and can be utilized offline. It is capable of translating the text and the generated text files can be used as subtitles when playing the source video.
AI Resources for OSINT: Face Swap - Face Swap is an artificial intelligence (AI) model capable of morphing multiple profile pictures to generate a "fake" profile picture that appears real.

AI Resources for OSINT: Concierge - Concierge is an open-source LLM which is able to run on low-powered hardware and ingest new information to incorporate into its analysis via retrieval-augmented generation (RAG).

SEC497: Practical Open-Source Intelligence (OSINT) - SEC497 is based on two decades of experience with OSINT research and investigations supporting law enforcement, intelligence operations, and a variety of private sector businesses ranging from small start-ups to Fortune 100 companies. The goal is to provide practical, real-world tools and techniques to help individuals perform OSINT research safely and effectively. One of the most dynamic aspects of working with professionals from different industries worldwide is getting to see their problems and working with them to help solve those problems. SEC497 draws on lessons learned over the years in OSINT to help others. The course not only covers critical OSINT tools and techniques, it also provides real-world examples of how they have been used to solve a problem or further an investigation. Hands-on labs based on actual scenarios provide students with the opportunity to practice the skills they learn and understand how those skills can help in their research. SEC497 includes 29 hands-on labs and a Capstone Capture-the-Flag event. GIAC Certification: GIAC Open Source Intelligence (GOSI)

SEC587: Advanced Open-Source Intelligence (OSINT) Gathering and Analysis - With OSINT being the engine of most major investigations in this digital age, the need for a more advanced course was inevitable. The data in almost every OSINT investigation becomes more complex to collect, exploit, and analyze. To address this reality, OSINT practitioners must be able to perform OSINT at scale and possess the means and methods to check and report on the reliability of their analysis. In SEC587 you will learn how to perform advanced OSINT gathering and analysis as well as understand and use common programming languages such as JSON and Python. SEC587 also will go into dark web and financial (cryptocurrency) topics as well as disinformation, advanced image, and video OSINT analysis. This is an advanced, fast-paced course that will give seasoned OSINT investigators new techniques and methodologies and entry-level OSINT analysts that extra depth in finding, collecting, and analyzing data sources from all around the world. GIAC Certification: GIAC Strategic OSINT Analyst (GSOA)
Command Line Kung Fu - View the contents of a file: Linux: cat file.txt | Windows: type file.txt
Command Line Kung Fu - Limit results to a line that contains a specific term: Linux: cat file.txt | grep -I sans | Windows: type file.txt | findstr -I sans
Command Line Kung Fu - Find out how many lines contain that term: Linux: cat file.txt | grep -I sans | wc -l | Windows: type file.txt | findstr -I sans | find /c /v ""
Command Line Kung Fu - Send the selected output to a new file: Linux: cat file.txt | grep -I sans > new_file.txt | Windows: type file.txt | findstr -I sans > new_file.txt
Dark Web Resources on the Internet: ahmia.fi - Fantastic (and free) dark web search engine
Dark Web Resources on the Internet: Tor.taxi - Trusted directory of sites on the dark web
Dark Web Resources on the Internet: Tor.link - Directory of sites on the dark web
Dark Web Resources on the Internet: Daunt.link - Trusted directory of sites on the dark web
Dark Web Resources on the Internet: Torry.io - Dark web search engine

Dark Web Resources on the Internet: https://github.com/fastfire/deepdarkCTI - Incredible list of URLS for dark websites including: Forums such as Dread, XSS, Exploit, etc., Ransomware blogs, Marketplaces

Tor Browser as a Proxy - When you start the Tor Browser, it automatically opens a proxy listener on port 9050 and/or 9150. Any application that can be configured to use this proxy will have its traffic routed through Tor and will be able to access the dark web. This functionality has many uses including being able to use Chrome/Firefox etc. and their plugins to gather information from dark websites as well as add the ability to access the dark web with your Python code.

Discord - A Discord server is a community space where users can chat, share media, and participate in various activities. Servers are divided into text channels (for chat) and voice channels (for voice communication). There are both public and private servers. Public servers are open to anyone and often focused on specific topics or interests. Private servers require an invitation to join and are usually for more exclusive or private groups. To find servers, use the "Explore Public Servers" option to search by category or interest.
Discord Dork: site:discord.gg - Explanation: Searches for pages that contain Discord invite links from the primary domain used for Discord invites
Discord Dork: site:discord.gg "gaming community" - Explanation: Adds specific keywords related to the topic or interest (e.g., "gaming community") to find relevant servers
Discord Dork: filetype:pdf "discord invite" - Explanation: Looks for PDF documents containing Discord invite links - can also use filetype:txt, filetype:doc, etc.
Discord Dork: site:reddit.com "discord.gg" "cybersecurity" - Explanation: Combines keywords with site-specific searches to find Discord invites posted on Reddit, which often shares server invites
Discord Dork: inurl:discord.gg "music community" - Explanation: Uses the inurl operator to search for URLs that contain specific text such as "discord.gg" combined with keywords
Discord Dork: site:forum.example.com "discord invite" - Explanation: Targets specific forums (replace forum.example.com with the URL of the forum) to find Discord invites

Discord Dork: intitle:"discord invite" "technology" - Explanation: Uses the intitle operator to search for pages with specific words in the title, useful for finding blog posts or articles mentioning Discord invites

Discord Dork: site:discord.com inurl:invite "art community" - Explanation: Combines site and inurl operators with a specific keyword to narrow the search to Discord's own domain for invites related to art communities
Discord Dork: site:twitter.com "discord.gg" "book club" - Explanation: Targets social media platforms where users share Discord invites by combining the site operator with keywords
Discord Dork: site:pastebin.com "discord.gg" - Explanation: Pastebin and similar sites are often used to share collections of links and can be a source for Discord invites
Discord Dork: site:facebook.com "discord.gg" "fitness" - Explanation: Targets specific community-driven platforms like Facebook to find groups that share Discord server links
Discord Dork: site:discord.gg "FPS gaming" - Explanation: Searches for pages containing Discord invites specifically mentioning "FPS gaming"
Discord Dork: site:reddit.com/r/cybersecurity "discord.gg" - Explanation: Targets the Reddit cybersecurity community for shared Discord invites
Discord Dork: filetype:txt "discord.gg" "study group" - Explanation: Searches for text files containing Discord invites related to study groups

metadata.title: Discord Dork - Study Group Text Files

text: Discord Dork: intitle:"discord invite" "tech news" - Explanation: Finds blog posts or articles with titles indicating they contain Discord invites related to tech news

Telegram - Telegram is a cloud-based instant messaging app that allows users to send messages, share media, and create groups and channels for broadcasting messages to large audiences. It is known for its focus on privacy, encryption, and speed. These Telegram channels are often used by members of the criminal underground to exchange ideas and information such as breach data and information stealer logs. Additionally, they serve as marketplaces where illicit goods and services, including stolen credentials, hacking tools, and illegal substances, are bought and sold. Telegram has a built-in search functionality which can help you find users and channels.
Telegram Dork: site:t.me - Explanation: Searches for pages that contain Telegram links from the t.me domain
Telegram Dork: site:t.me "cybersecurity" - Explanation: Adds specific keywords related to the topic (e.g., "cybersecurity") to find relevant Telegram links
Telegram Dork: filetype:pdf "telegram invite" - Explanation: Looks for PDF documents containing Telegram invite links - can also use filetype:txt, filetype:doc, etc.
Telegram Dork: site:reddit.com "telegram invite" "cybersecurity" - Explanation: Combines keywords with site-specific searches to find Telegram invites posted on Reddit, often shared in discussions
Telegram Dork: inurl:t.me "trading group" - Explanation: Uses the inurl operator to search for URLs that contain specific text, such as "t.me", combined with keywords
Telegram Dork: site:forum.example.com "telegram invite" - Explanation: Targets specific forums (replace forum.example.com with the URL of the forum) to find Telegram invites

Telegram Dork: intitle:"telegram invite" "cryptocurrency" - Explanation: Uses the intitle operator to search for pages with specific words in the title, useful for finding blog posts or articles mentioning Telegram invites
Telegram Dork: site:twitter.com "t.me" "book club" - Explanation: Targets social media platforms where users share Telegram invites by combining the site operator with keywords
Telegram Dork: site:pastebin.com "t.me" - Explanation: Pastebin and similar sites are often used to share collections of links and can be a source for Telegram invites
Telegram Dork: site:facebook.com "telegram invite" "fitness" - Explanation: Targets specific community-driven platforms like Facebook to find groups that share Telegram server links
Telegram Dork: site:t.me "hacking group" - Explanation: Searches for pages containing Telegram invites specifically mentioning "hacking group"
Telegram Dork: site:reddit.com/r/OSINT "telegram invite" - Explanation: Targets the Reddit OSINT community for shared Telegram invites
Telegram Dork: filetype:txt "t.me" "study group" - Explanation: Searches for text files containing Telegram invites related to study groups

metadata.title: Telegram Dork - Study Group Text Files

text: Telegram Dork: intitle:"telegram channel" "tech news" - Explanation: Finds blog posts or articles with titles indicating they contain Telegram invites related to tech news
Detecting AI Content - As AI models become more sophisticated, detecting AI-generated content has become more challenging.

Detecting AI Content Method: Look for repetitive phrases and ideas - AI-generated content often includes repetitive phrases, sentences, or ideas. This happens because the model might generate similar outputs based on its training data. Identifying repetitive patterns, especially unusual repetition, can be a strong indicator of machine-generated text.

Detecting AI Content Method: Check for inconsistent writing styles - AI might produce content with sudden changes in tone or style. For example, a paragraph might switch from formal to informal language abruptly. These inconsistencies occur because AI models might pull from varied data sources, leading to a lack of uniformity in writing style.

Detecting AI Content Method: Identify odd word choices or phrasing - AI models sometimes use words or phrases in ways that seem slightly off or uncommon. This can include the use of synonyms that don't fit the context perfectly or awkward sentence constructions that a native speaker wouldn't typically use.

Detecting AI Content Method: Assess the depth of content - AI-generated text might lack the depth and nuance of human writing. While it can produce coherent and informative content, it often misses the detailed insights, unique perspectives, or expert knowledge that a human writer would provide.

Detecting AI Content Method: Verify factual accuracy - AI-generated content can include inaccurate information. It's essential to cross-check facts with reliable sources. AI may generate plausible-sounding but incorrect facts, especially when discussing niche or complex topics, making thorough verification critical.

Detecting AI Content Method: Analyze sentence structure and linguistic patterns - AI models may use more complex or unnatural sentence structures compared to human writers. Look for overly complex sentences, unusual grammar patterns, or repetitive sentence structures. These linguistic anomalies can signal that the text is machine-generated.

Detecting AI Content Method: Monitor posting behavior - Frequent, high-volume content posting without a corresponding number of human interactions can be a sign of AI-generated content. Analyze the posting frequency and engagement metrics. AI-generated posts might flood a platform with content at a rate that is impractical for human users.

Detecting AI Content Method: Examine user engagement patterns - AI-generated content might attract different engagement patterns compared to human content. For instance, such content might receive fewer meaningful comments or generate engagement that seems automated. Human users tend to engage in more nuanced and varied ways.

Detecting AI Content - Specific Prompt Error Messages to Search For: "As an AI language model", "I'm sorry, I cannot generate", "Not a recognized word", "Cannot provide a phrase", "Violates OpenAI's content policy"

metadata.title: Detecting AI - Error Messages to Search

text: Cryptocurrency Research Resource: Breadcrumbs.app - Breadcrumbs provides attribution (Coinbase, Binance, etc.) on over 50 million Ethereum and Bitcoin addresses. Breadcrumbs offers free plans and paid plans much cheaper than other solutions in the space.
Cryptocurrency Research Resource: Blockchain.com - The blockchain.com explorer offers visibility into blockchains for Bitcoin, Bitcoin Cash, and Ethereum.

Cryptocurrency Research Resource: Walletexplorer.com - Wallet Explorer groups cryptocurrency addresses together by wallet ID. It can help determine what site (dark web marketplace, cryptocurrency exchange, etc.) an address is tied to.
Cryptocurrency Research Resource: Chainabuse.com - Chainabuse is a site where scam-related cryptocurrency addresses are reported and researched.

Cryptocurrency Research Resource: OpenSanctions.com - OpenSanctions is an international database of persons and companies of political, criminal, or economic interest. The site contains datasets from over 120 sources, some of which have cryptocurrency wallet addresses for sanctioned individuals and/or groups.

Cryptocurrency Research Resource: ArkhamIntelligence.com - Arkham Intelligence is a site with a large amount of information on which site/service a wallet address is tied to. It has its own cryptocurrency (ARKM) which it uses for an Intel Exchange where users can post bounties for information and/or sets of information for sale. Common listings include bounties to help identify the individuals behind cryptocurrency scams and users selling lists of wallets tied to known investment firms to see where and when they move funds.

The Admiralty Code (AKA NATO System) is a relatively simple scheme for categorizing evidence according to its credibility. It was initially used by the British Admiralty for the assessment of evidence used in naval intelligence, but it is now used in many police departments, intelligence agencies, and defense-related organizations, including the U.S. Army. (U.S. Army Field Manual 2-22.3, 2006)
Admiralty Code - Source Rating A (Reliable): No doubt of authenticity, trustworthiness, or competency, has a history of complete reliability
Admiralty Code - Source Rating B (Usually reliable): Minor doubt about authenticity, trustworthiness, or competency, has a history of valid information most of the time

metadata.title: Admiralty Code - Source B Usually Reliable

text: Admiralty Code - Source Rating C (Fairly reliable): Doubt of authenticity, trustworthiness, or competency, but had provided valid information in the past

metadata.title: Admiralty Code - Source C Fairly Reliable

text: Admiralty Code - Source Rating D (Not usually reliable): Significant doubt about authenticity, trustworthiness, or competency, but had provided valid information in the past

metadata.title: Admiralty Code - Source D Not Usually Reliable

text: Admiralty Code - Source Rating E (Unreliable): Lacking authenticity, trustworthiness, or competency, has a history of invalid information
Admiralty Code - Source Rating F (Cannot be judged): No basis for evaluating the reliability of the source

metadata.title: Admiralty Code - Source F Cannot Be Judged

text: Admiralty Code - Content Rating 1 (Confirmed): Confirmed by other independent sources, logical in itself, consistent with other information on the subject
Admiralty Code - Content Rating 2 (Probably true): Not confirmed, logical in itself, consistent with other information on the subject
Admiralty Code - Content Rating 3 (Possibly true): Not confirmed, reasonably logical, agrees with some other information on the subject
Admiralty Code - Content Rating 4 (Doubtfully true): Not confirmed, possible but not logical, no other information on the subject
Admiralty Code - Content Rating 5 (Improbable): Not confirmed, not logical in itself, contradicted by other information on the subject
Admiralty Code - Content Rating 6 (Misinformation): Unintentionally false, not logical in itself, contradicted by other information on the subject, confirmed by other independent sources
Admiralty Code - Content Rating 7 (Deception): Deliberately false, contradicted by other information on the subject, confirmed by other independent sources
Admiralty Code - Content Rating 8 (Cannot be judged): No basis for evaluating the reliability of the source

metadata.title: Admiralty Code - Content 8 Cannot Be Judged

text: Admiralty Code Matrix for Evaluating the Credibility of Evidence: Credible (accept) - ratings in green zone, Uncertain (investigate/wait) - ratings in yellow zone, Non-credible (reject) - ratings in red zone. Matrix combines Source (A-F) with Content (1-8) ratings.

Business Research Resource: The Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project (OCCRP) - The OCCRP provides an index of country specific resources for researching businesses across the world. https://id.occrp.org/databases

Business Research Resource: The UK's Companies House - In addition to UK coverage, the UK Companies House has a page listing several company registries from other countries. www.gov.uk/government/publications/overseas-registries/overseas-registries

Business Research Resource: Chinese Business Registries - Chinese Business Registries can provide details about Chinese companies including telephone numbers, email addresses, historical names, date of formation, legal representative, shareholders, executives, officers, directors, Chinese Unified Social Credit Score, and document filing history. Qcc.com & Qixin.com
Business Research Resource: OpenCorporates - OpenCorporates crawls the web, aggregates corporate ownership information, and structures it for free public use. OpenCorporates.com

Business Research Resource: Open Sanctions - Open Sanctions is a free international database of persons and companies of political, criminal, or economic interest that provides raw data from over 60 sources in downloadable formats. OpenSanctions.org

Business Research Resource: SEC EDGAR Database - www.sec.gov/edgar/search-and-access. EDGAR is a database of corporate filings maintained by the Securities Exchange Commission (SEC) that can be difficult to search, but provides a wealth of information. Investigative journalist organization Bellingcat recently released a Python tool that can make acquiring information from EDGAR much easier. The tool is available here: https://github.com/bellingcat/EDGAR

Report Writing - Executive Summary (AKA Key Findings, Bottom Line Up Front (BLUF), etc.): Unfortunately, no matter how great a report is, some people will only spend a few minutes reviewing it. To make sure that we convey the most important findings to those individuals, we need an executive summary section at the beginning of our report.

Report Writing - Methodology: One of the key components of digital forensics is that if two forensics practitioners receive the same evidence, analyze it, and report their findings, they should both come to very similar conclusions. OSINT is similar, and the methodology section is where you describe at a high level the methods used in your research and analysis. Methodology helps others understand how something was accomplished so another practitioner can verify the results. When results are scarce, the methodology section is more important than ever to let others know what you tried. This not only conveys how much effort you put into your research, but can help others avoid wasting time trying the same techniques you did.

Report Writing - Findings: The findings section likely represents the bulk of your report, and in addition to your writeup, it can include images, screenshots, tables, etc. One of the most important things for an analyst to provide is an explanation of why things are important. Analysts who focus on a particular area often believe that what they know, others know as well, but that's often not the case. You likely have knowledge or context that others viewing the report may not, so you need to convey that information where possible to help answer the "so what?" question.

Report Writing - Appendices: One of the most difficult parts of report writing is meeting the needs of a majority of people who read your report. As a general rule, shorter reports are preferred over large ones. The executive summary meets the needs of those only spending a few minutes with your report, while the main body of the report meets the needs of someone spending a little more time. But what about another OSINT practitioner who receives a task based off your report? The report you generate may be the end of the journey on that particular topic, but someone else may receive that report and use it as the starting point for their own research. In the case of your report being a starting point, that individual would likely appreciate more details, including some of the "raw" information, that anyone else reading the report would likely just gloss over. To help meet this goal, appendices are a fantastic tool. Raw output from tools or other sources that are summarized in your report can be placed in an appendix and included as an attachment with your report. Having an executive summary, a concise report, and additional raw information included as appendices can help ensure that your report meets the diverse needs of all readers.
